may be seen; which, judging from my own personal
experience, I conceive to be quite unnecessary. This 
part is illustrated by drawings, and by explanations of 
the principles of perspective applicable to them; which
would be very fit for an elementary treateise on astronomy
but are totally unfit for the publications of the Royal
Society.

Then follow historical notices of the discovery and 
observations of and theoretical speculations on, the Zodiacal Light, which would
be interesting and valuable in their proper place; I
think however that this is not their proper place.

This is followed by a description of the simple
Equatoreal recommended for measures of the Zodiacal
Light; with detailed precepts for its adjustment, 
such as would be required by a person who possesses
no previous knowledge whatever of the Instrument.
These I conceive are entirely out of place.

On the whole paper I have to remark as
follows.

The only part, which conveys new information to me,
and (I shall think) to other persons, is the seven
determinations of the place of the point of the Zodiacal
